title: target="_blank" Vulnerability Resulting in Critical Phishing Vector

summaries.content:
On September 1st, 2016, @n0rb3r7 reported a vulnerability in the [Mapbox Classic editor](https://www.mapbox.com/editor/) related to a known `window.opener.location.href` issue with user generated content and cross origin navigation when `target="_blank"` (see [HTML bug report](https://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=28821)). This was addressed via the creation of the `noopener` link attribute (see [whatwg PR](https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/290)) and browser compatibility efforts are ongoing. As of now it is has [limited support](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#link-type-noopener), though there are open tickets for adding it to the majority of remaining browsers.

After an internal review of the issue- taking into consideration previous reports similar in nature, browser compatibility progress towards making `noopener` the default, the level of effort necessary to attempt this exploit, the bandwith required for patching it, as well as the fact that Mapbox Classic editor is a legacy product- we decided that we would not move forward with an immediate fix at this time.

This report was well put together and looking into it helped us further our research on this vulnerability type, thank you again @n0rb3r7!
summaries.content_html:
On September 1st, 2016, @n0rb3r7 reported a vulnerability in the Mapbox Classic editor related to a known window.opener.location.href issue with user generated content and cross origin navigation when target="_blank" (see HTML bug report). This was addressed via the creation of the noopener link attribute (see whatwg PR) and browser compatibility efforts are ongoing. As of now it is has limited support, though there are open tickets for adding it to the majority of remaining browsers.

After an internal review of the issue- taking into consideration previous reports similar in nature, browser compatibility progress towards making noopener the default, the level of effort necessary to attempt this exploit, the bandwith required for patching it, as well as the fact that Mapbox Classic editor is a legacy product- we decided that we would not move forward with an immediate fix at this time.

This report was well put together and looking into it helped us further our research on this vulnerability type, thank you again @n0rb3r7!

activities.message:
Thank you for your report.

I don't believe I can access your map before its public, using the URL you have provided.  If I navigate to that link, I am asked to login to Mapbox, and when I log in to *my* Mapbox account, (rather than your Mapbox account), I cannot access your map.  Are you able to show a PoC that affects other Mapbox users?

Thanks, and good luck with your future bug hunting.
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your report.

I don't believe I can access your map before its public, using the URL you have provided. If I navigate to that link, I am asked to login to Mapbox, and when I log in to my Mapbox account, (rather than your Mapbox account), I cannot access your map. Are you able to show a PoC that affects other Mapbox users?

Thanks, and good luck with your future bug hunting.

activities.message: Hi @bugtriage-josh! Thank you for the quick reply. My apologies, I didn't think about you not having access to my account (Duh! If you did, I think that would warrant a big bug bounty in itself.) One specific delivery vector that would impact other Mapbox users would be to have the user create a new Mapbox Studio Classic Project by importing the following JSON. ``` {"type":"FeatureCollection","features":[{"type":"Feature","properties":{"id":"marker-iskojtdy0","title":"Marker","description":"Click here","marker-size":"medium","marker-color":"#1087bf","marker-symbol":""},"geometry":{"coordinates":[2.285156,24.206889],"type":"Point"},"id":"b1b9753756f0d6828142e38471010e0b"}],"id":"chasemiller5.19coghk8"} ``` In this case, the steps to reproduce are: 1. Log into your Mapbox account and navigate to Mapbox classic > Mapbox editor project > New Mapbox Editor Project 2. Once in the new project, navigate to Data > Import a JSON file containing the above JSON > Complete Importing 3. After importing, the single point should appear. Click on this point, and then the "Here" link would hijack the user's legitimate Mapbox dashboard tab and redirect the user to my phishing page. While this particular phishing attack vector is elaborate (and may be a bit of a stretch), it could be a legitimate concern. Thanks, Chase
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @bugtriage-josh!

Thank you for the quick reply. My apologies, I didn't think about you not having access to my account (Duh! If you did, I think that would warrant a big bug bounty in itself.)

One specific delivery vector that would impact other Mapbox users would be to have the user create a new Mapbox Studio Classic Project by importing the following JSON. 

{"type":"FeatureCollection","features":[{"type":"Feature","properties":{"id":"marker-iskojtdy0","title":"Marker","description":"<a href=\"http://chasemiller.me/hax/mapbox_test.html\">Click here</a>","marker-size":"medium","marker-color":"#1087bf","marker-symbol":""},"geometry":{"coordinates":[2.285156,24.206889],"type":"Point"},"id":"b1b9753756f0d6828142e38471010e0b"}],"id":"chasemiller5.19coghk8"}

In this case, the steps to reproduce are:

  1. Log into your Mapbox account and navigate to Mapbox classic > Mapbox editor project > New Mapbox Editor Project
  2. Once in the new project, navigate to Data > Import a JSON file containing the above JSON > Complete Importing
  3. After importing, the single point should appear. Click on this point, and then the "Here" link would hijack the user's legitimate Mapbox dashboard tab and redirect the user to my phishing page.

While this particular phishing attack vector is elaborate (and may be a bit of a stretch), it could be a legitimate concern.

Thanks,
Chase

activities.message: Attaching the json file to make your life easier if you wanted to test it.
activities.markdown_message: Attaching the json file to make your life easier if you wanted to test it.

@n0rb3r7 -- thank you again for the great report!

We've had this issue reported to us in the past and have been keeping an eye on associated rel=noopener threads (e.g. HTML spec, Chrome, Firefox). At this point we've decided to hold off a bit and see how the cross platform debate/patching of this issue progresses prior to moving forward with mitigating it on our end. In addition, Mapbox classic editor is a legacy product and the level of effort necessary to effectively exploit this vulnerability is relatively high. Given these factors, we don't feel the severity of this issue merits an immediate fix and will be closing this report as informative.

Thank you for thinking of Mapbox security and happy bug hunting!

activities.message:
Hi @kmahoney!

Thank you for the reply! :) I completely understand the decision, as it is a widely debated "vulnerability". Some programs have considered it to be a valid vulnerability while others have not. This one in particular was a stretch due to the delivery mechanism.

I am working on a blog post discussing the vulnerability and my findings across several major sites and their responses. As such I am requesting public disclosure.

Thanks again!
@n0rb3r7
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @kmahoney!

Thank you for the reply! :) I completely understand the decision, as it is a widely debated "vulnerability". Some programs have considered it to be a valid vulnerability while others have not. This one in particular was a stretch due to the delivery mechanism.

I am working on a blog post discussing the vulnerability and my findings across several major sites and their responses. As such I am requesting public disclosure.

Thanks again!
@n0rb3r7

activities.message: Absolutely. Mind sending a link to the post my way when it's done? We'd love to read it!
activities.markdown_message: Absolutely. Mind sending a link to the post my way when it's done? We'd love to read it!

vulnerability_information_html:
Description
I have a script running on my server which gives me full control over a visitor's window object. This allows me to replace the user's legitimate mapbox.com session with my own Mapbox phishing form (not live). As you can see from the proof-of-concept video below, this vulnerability works cross-origin. This is an extremely effective phishing vector and should be remediated ASAP.

Video PoC:

Reproduction Steps:

  1. Navigate to my map at https://www.mapbox.com/editor/?id=chasemiller5.19coghk8#data
  2. Click on my website link in the description (http://chasemiller.me/hax/mapbox_test.html)
  3. This should open the link and change the user's legitimate mapbox.com session to my malicious Mapbox login phishing page (not active) (behavior may vary slightly between browsers).

Mitigation:
This bug can be easily mitigated by using the 'noopener' link type. This sets the 'window.opener' property to 'null'
vulnerability_information:
**Description**
I have a script running on my server which gives me full control over a visitor's window object. This allows me to replace the user's legitimate mapbox.com session with my own Mapbox phishing form (not live). As you can see from the proof-of-concept video below, this vulnerability works cross-origin. This is an extremely effective phishing vector and should be remediated ASAP. 

**Video PoC:** {F116642}

**Reproduction Steps:**
1. Navigate to my map at https://www.mapbox.com/editor/?id=chasemiller5.19coghk8#data
2. Click on my website link in the description (http://chasemiller.me/hax/mapbox_test.html) 
3. This should open the link and change the user's legitimate mapbox.com session to my malicious Mapbox login phishing page (not active) (behavior may vary slightly between browsers).

**Mitigation:**
This bug can be easily mitigated by using the 'noopener' link type. This sets the 'window.opener' property to 'null'

profile.about: Mapbox is an open source mapping platform for developers. We make it easy to integrate location into any mobile or online application.
profile.name: Mapbox
